title: ASL 4.5 — Storytelling Frames ⏳➡️
objectives: Use timeline markers PAST, FUTURE, FINISH, and NEXT to structure short stories
Anchor people/places in space and maintain consistency across clauses
Apply light ROLE-SHIFT for quoted actions or dialogue while keeping clauses compact (3–5 signs)

vocab.def: Move toward back space or use specific time words.
Move forward in space; point ahead in timeline.
Completion marker; often placed after verb or clause.
Place people/places at fixed points (LEFT/RIGHT/FRONT) for reuse.
Small body/eye shift to show another character’s perspective.

sections.heading: Warm-Up: Timeline & Sequencers
sections.body: Drill **PAST, FUTURE, FINISH, NEXT** along a simple line: back (past) → neutral (now) → forward (future). Keep motion small and repeatable.

callouts.title: Tiny, Not Huge
callouts.body: Keep timeline moves small; clarity beats size.

sections.heading: Model: Time-First Story Frames

media.alt: PAST SCHOOL, NEXT HOME, FUTURE GAME.
media.caption: 3–5 sign clauses; light pauses

sections.body:
Use **TIME → SUBJECT → ACTION → (FINISH)**. Examples:
• **PAST MORNING I GO SCHOOL.**
• **NEXT I GO HOME FINISH.**
• **FUTURE TONIGHT WE PLAY GAME.** Keep a tiny pause after the time chunk.
sections.teacherNote: Coach a micro-pause between clauses to prevent run-ons.

sections.heading: Anchoring: People & Places

media.alt: Anchor Person-A left, Person-B right, Place top-right
media.caption: Reuse the same points every time

sections.body: Set **PERSON-A** (left), **PERSON-B** (right), **PLACE** (upper-right). Reuse these points in later clauses to avoid confusion.

options: Reuse the same point for each referent

sections.heading: ROLE-SHIFT (RS): Quick Quotes
sections.body:
For short dialogue/action, shift shoulders/eye gaze slightly to the character’s anchor point. Example:
• Narrator: **PAST PERSON-A MEET PERSON-B.**
• RS→A: **HI.**
• RS→B: **WHAT’S-UP?** Keep RS brief; return to neutral for narration.

callouts.title: Keep It Light
callouts.body: Small body shift + eye gaze is enough—don’t wander from anchors.

microCheck.q: After a role-shift line, you should…

sections.heading: Partner Practice: 3-Beat Story
sections.body: Build a 3-beat mini story: **PAST** (setup), **NEXT** (action), **FUTURE** (plan). Include **one** brief RS line. Swap roles.

callouts.title: Clause Size
callouts.body: Aim 3–5 signs per beat. Add **FINISH** to mark completed actions.

sections.heading: Mini-Showcase
sections.body: Record **10–15s**: 3-beat story with **PAST → NEXT → FUTURE** and **one RS line**. Example: **PAST I STUDY. NEXT TEST FINISH. FUTURE I CELEBRATE. (RS friend) NICE!**
sections.teacherNote: Privacy submissions OK; caption should name your anchors (A/B/PLACE).

items.q: Which movement maps PAST on a timeline?
Best base order for story clauses:
After a ROLE-SHIFT line, return to…
Write a 3-clause gloss using PAST, NEXT, FUTURE with one FINISH.

items.prompt: Which was trickier—keeping anchors consistent or timing your RS returns? What cue will you practice?

reflectionPrompt: Upload your 10–15s 3-beat story (PAST → NEXT → FUTURE + one RS). Caption your anchors and where you used FINISH.
summary: You mapped time on a simple timeline, sequenced events with NEXT/FINISH, anchored referents, and used light role-shift for quick dialogue.
